subSubSection.paragraph:
Protoneura sanguinipes nec Westfall, 1987
—
Westfall (1987: 94; paratype 798 from Villa Anacaona)
. Misidentification.

subSubSection.paragraph:

Diagnosis. Male cercus, with a medial sclerotized branch which ends on a tooth directed medioventrally and remainder of cercus foliaceous, medially concave, with a small triangular tooth on outer ventrobasal edge, and a long, curved thick pointed tooth at medial ventrobasal edge directed medially ( Fig. 106 ), is shared with
P. caligata
,
P. capillaris
,
P. sanguinipes
, and
P. viridis
( Figs. 100 ; 102; 113; 117). Within this group,
P. dunklei
resembles
P. sanguinipes
by the medial sclerotized branch of male cercus ending on a broad triangular tip located at about midlength of cercus ( Figs. 106 ; 113) and by distal margin of genital ligula triangularly convex with laterodistal corners not projected ventrally ( Figs. 80 ; 87); in
P. caligata
,
P. capillaris
, and
P. viridis
the medial branch ends on a tooth directed medioventrally located at cercus tip ( Figs. 100 ; 102; 117), and distal margin of genital ligula is straight with laterodistal corners projected ventrally ( Figs. 74 ; 76; 93).
Protoneura dunklei
differs from males of all four species by the black basal half of femora outer surface ( Fig. 10 ), which is pale in the other species ( Figs. 4 ; 6; 17; 21). Female can be distinguished from all congeners except
P. sanguinipes
by its trilobed posterior lobe of pronotum directed dorsally and with medial lobe entire and smoothly convex (as in Fig. 63a) and by oval mesostigmal plate (Figs. 56; 63b). It differs by flexor surface of tibiae dark ( Fig. 34 ; pale in
P. sanguinipes
, Fig. 41 ).
Distribution. Dominican Republic ( Fig. 119 ). Assessed as Least concern by IUCN ( Paulson 2009e ).
